The Alumni Association, the
Alumni Council, the Johns Hopkins Club, and other alumni organizations are co-operating in a
movement for a general reunion
of Hopkins alumni in June. This
will be the first gathering of former Hopkins men since the move
to Homewood was made. There
had been an insistent call for a
number of years from the alumni
that the University be moved to
Homewood. They will now have
an opportunity to see what a
splendid start has been made by
the University in that direction
and to form an impression as to
what there is yet to be done to
complete the job.
The principal reason for having
a reunion at this time is that it
is a most appropriate time for all
to unite in memorial exercises to
those of the alumni who have lost
their lives in the World War. It
will also afford a splendid opportunity to pay fit tribute to
alumni who have, returned from
the war and to welcome them.
The plans for the reunion are
still somewhat incomplete. They
will include an inspection of
Homewood by the alumni, memorial exercises to the dead and
the erection of a memorial tablet.
A number of features of a lighter
nature will be incorporated; for
instance, a lacrosse game with
the University of Toronto a baseball game, a smoker at the Johns
Hopkins Club, a review of the R.
0. T. C. battalion, class and department dinners and reunions.
Theoretically speaking, the reunion will come to an end Saturday night, June 21. A number
of very interesting features are
planned, however, for the interval
between that date and the commencement on June 24. A number of very prominent officials of
the United States and Canada
will be present at this time
time, and
a cable was sent to Dr.
who is now in Europe, to endeavor to secure the presence of
Dr. Osler.
If the Peace Conference does
not interfere, the committee plans
to have present at the meeting. President Wilson, Secretary
Baker, both Hopkins alumni, and
also the Prime Minister of Canada.

Against a field of the best athletes in the South, the Black and
Blue squad amassed a total of
561/2 points and tied Georgetown
in the South. Atlantic Intercollegiate Championships held Saturday on Homewood Field. The
six highest point winners for
Hopkins were: B. Smith, 10
points; G. Leadbetter, 10; W. V.
Evans, 51/2; J. Bartels, 5; W.
Driver, 5; B. VanNess, 5.
Beverly Smith provided the
sensation for the meet when he
ran the quarter mile in 51 seconds flat over a soggy track. He
not only lowered the Hopkins
record, but showed that he will
be a close competitor for the collegiate record in the I. C. A. A.
A. A. on May 31. Taking the
lead at the start, Bev crossed the
line twenty yards ahead of McClure of V. P. I. After winning
the 440, Smith came back and
took first honors in the half mile,
drawing out from third place on
the last turn with a sprint which
brought him across the finish
with a safe margin.
Guy Leadbetter won his two
first places again, none of the
other entries being able to compete with him in the shot or
discus. In the coming Lafayette
meet, Leadbetter may be counted
upon for a third first, as the hammer throw another of his specialthe list for that meet.

In the distant events, Hopkins
had things all her own way.
Smith took first in the half mile.
Driver coming in for a third,
with L. Cattanach at his elbow
a good fourth. Bartels ran an
excellent mile, and considering
the nature of the track, his time
of 4 minutes 40 3-5 seconds would
be lowered by eight or ten seconds under favorable conditions.
W. Norwood placed fifth in the
same event.
In the two-mile run, Mullikin
led until Grave his team-mate,
passed him on the fifth lap; at
the last turn on the final round,_
both men droped back a place
when Linkin of V. P. I. sprinted
and crossed the tape two yards to
the good.
W. V. Evans won his letter
with a total of five and one-half
points, tieing for third in the
high jump, and gaining a dear
title to the same place in the pole
vault. Seagrave cleared the bar
for second place in the , same

Kirk, Simon, Thomsen, Bartels, Benson

Burger, Silberstein and Wyckoff
Chosen by Honorary Society—Dr.
Slonimsky Faculty Member.

The Omicron Delta ,Kappa $ociety held its. annual election of
members on May 6, and a report
from the committee on sending
speakers to "prep" schools in
Maryland was made.
The meeting was preceded by
a luncheon at.the ,Hopkins Club.
Carl Schmidt, president of the
circle, presided. The newly elected members of the senior Class
are: H. E. Kirk, L. Simon and
R. C. Thomsen; of the junior
Class are: J. R. Bartels, C. D.
Benson, T. T. Burger, S. gilberstein and V. J. Wyckoff; no sophomores wete elected. Dr. Henry
Slonimsky was elected its a faculty member. He will fill the place
left vacant by Dr. Brush's departure.
The committee on sending
speakers to "prep" schools in
Maryland, composed of G. Cattanach, A. B. Coleman and C. T.
Leber, reported that everything
was in readiness for the first
trip. The high schools in Baltimore and the vicinity will be visited first. These visits are to be
made in order to interest future
college students in Hopkins, and
to get them to come to the University after graduating from high
school.
The faculty members present at.
the meeting were: Dean Latane,
Dr. Roulston, Dr. Tilden and
Capt. Guild.

Prof. David M. Robinson recently gave an illustrated lecture at
Wilson College, Chambersburg,
Pa., on "The Seven Churches of
Asia." .He is going to New York
City to attend the meeting of the
managing committee of the American School of Classical Studies in
Athens.
While in New York, Dr. Robinson will read a paper on May 13,
on "War Memorials," before the
College Art Association, and will
discuss the same subject at the FOR FURTHER INFORMATION,SEE

Summer School Courses Announced.

The summe: courses of the University that were recently announced include courses in biology, chemistry, economics, educa-tion, English, fine arts, French,
German, history, Latin literature,
manual training, mathematics,
philosophy, politics, psychology,
and Spanish. Summer school will
be held from July 8 to August 15,
inclusive.

MANUFACTURERS OF

HIGH GRADE CHOCOLATES.

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Yale is the pioneer in restricting the number of activities in
which one student may take part.
All of the offices and memberships are divided into three
classes, and no man may accept
more than a certain number in
each class. In the recently held
elections for next year the system was followed. It has attracted considerable interest in
other colleges, and a similar proposal is to be made at Dartmouth.
The new system will be very
helpful as a measure against the
ascendancy of "job hogs," as certain members of the community
are respectfully named.
• *
Swarthmore raised over seven
hundred dollars in a recent campaign of the Child Labor committee.
* * *
Washington and Lee has established an honor system canteen,.
carrying on business without
even a clerk, and having all customers wait on themselves.
Dean Briggs of Harvard says
that tutors should be professors
with a voice'in the affairs of the
University, and with a permanent
position of honor. He decidedly
disfavors the seasonal coaching
system.

The annual Government inspectiOn of the R. 0. T. C. unit will
be held on .May 19 and 20. Col.
J. B. Douglas, of the General
Staff, will act as inspector. Judging from the way the R. 0. T. C.
has been drilling recently, and
from the plans that are laid, it
looks as though Hopkins will
maintain its old record for efficiency in R. 0. T. C. work. For
the inspection, there will be three
companies with cadet officers. All
members of the unit will form in
one or another of these companies.
LECTURER DISCUSSES "ORE DOCK
ON THE GREAT LAKES."

Last week's J. E. Aldred Lecture was on the subject of "Ore
Docks on the Great Lakes," and
was given by Mr..John E. Greiner,
consulting engineer of this city.
The chief topics dwelt upon were
the expansion of the ore-handling
business, the construction of the
docks (both loading and unloading) and the types of unloading
machinery.
The speaker began with saying
that the Sault Ste Marie Canal increased the shipments of ore from
1,450 tons to 36,000 in one year,
and that last year the output had
increased to 61,000,000 tons. Most
of the deposits are along the
southern shore of Lake Superior;
hence, the docks there are of the
loading kind, with high bins and
chutes to deliver the ore by gravity into the holds of the steamers.
The unloading docks along
Lakes Michigan, Erie and Huron
have huge scoops and buckets for
lifting the ore from the holds of•
the steamers and depositing it
upon storage piles or in cars. The
scoops act like giant hands, turning and twisting into every corner, under the control of the driver, who sometimes sits in a compartment on the scoop and sometimes on the crane.
This field of engineering, which
includes the design of docks and
their machinery, and the operation
and upkeep of the same, is still
in its infancy. The rapid growth
before the war and the wide possibilities of development in the future will afford many openings
for the young engineers.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAY 13, 1919

The June Reunion.

IS

The Alumni Reu nion, scheduled
for the latter part of June, should
be of great value to the University. Three of the main features
on the program are a thorough
inspection of the Homewood
buildings by the alumni, many
of whom have never seen Hopkins in its up-town home; memorial exercises, including the
erection of a memorial tablet to
the dead; and a welcome to Hopkins' sons who have returned
from overseas.
The alumni long advocated the
change of site from down-town
to Homewood; and now they, will
have a chance to see what is still
needed in the way of buildings
and equipment. The lack of adequate dormitories, a gym, laboratory buildings and the like, will
immediately be apparent. The
alumni are seeking a permanent
memorial for Hopkins men who
made the supreme sacrifice.
What could be more suitable than
a memorial dormitory or gymnasium?
It would be fitting for the present to have tablets to perpetuate
the memory of those who gave
their lives, but in the near future
a memorial building should by all
means be erected. Princeton is
considering for this purpose a
chapel; Washington and Lee, an
arch, and Lehigh is carrying on
a most successful campaign for a

memorial administration building, the first $100,000 having been
contributed by fifty men. The
Hopkins alumni are looked to to
help put the thing across for us;
and the reunion in June will
probably start a Hopkins memorial campaign.
The reunion plans and the
names of prominent alumni and
officials who will attend the reunion appear in another part of
the NEWS-LETTER. Mr. George
Radcliffe, president of the Alumni
Association, is exerting every effort for the success of the alumni
get-together. The students and
faculty, by their co-operation and
enthusiasm, can do much to aid
him and the committees in
charge. We should lend our aid
in every way toward making the
exercises in June one of the greatest events in the history of the
University. The NEWS-LETTER IS
planning to do its part by issuing
a special alumni number to be
sent to all parts of the country,
with the intention of interesting
the alumni.
The reunion, which will last
through commencement, will tend
to make the finals this year more
eventful. More elaborate finals
traditions would certainly be
most beneficial to Hopkins. The
Princeton finals, for example,
with their combination of dignity,
impressiveness and gaiety, are
the crowning event of the year.
Every class with surviving members returns to pay homage to its
Alma Mater. Each class has
its separate headquarters, where
song and reminiscence—and in
the future, Bevo — hold sway.
Social events for both undergraduates and older men crowd the
calendar. The alumni thus renew their zeal for Princeton and
form a veritable army to back it
financially and in every other
way.
Here at Hopkins, however, the
termination of the final exams
marks the closing of the year for
many. When the last dread
ordeal is a thing of the past, they
immediately repair to home or
resort. We hope that the coming
Alumni Reunion will be a forerunner of real Hopkins finals, in
which every class since the founding of the University and every
undergraduate will take an active
part.
Were You There?

The performance of the track
artists and stickmen Saturday
deserved better attendance. The
fair-weather rooters evidently
preferred the sheltering coziness
of some tea emporium to the cold
drizzle of Homewood field—or,
perhaps, hearing at Friday's
mass-meeting of the fate of all
head-gears not of the straw variety, and fearing the rain's effect on their new Knox, they just
didn't know what to wear. At
all events, they would have been
'rewarded for any trouble just to
have witnessed the lacrosse game,

which resulted in such a fiasco
for the Philadelphians. If the
Black and Blue stickmen can repeat next Saturday against
Lehigh, they will again bring the
championship to Hopkins.
The names of the nominees for
election to the G. A. A., appear
elsewhere in the NEWS-LETTER.
Consider them carefully and don't
fail to be present at the massmeeting Thursday. Your fee of
ten dollars makes you a stockholder in the Athletic Association. You surely want to help
determine its policy by voting for
your candidate. All out Thursday!
Particular attention has been
given NEWS-LETTER candidates
this year, for each has received
an informal grade on his work
every week. The four men who
were elected Monday have shown
the most dependability and talent
so far; others, however, will probably be elected before the end of
the year. The NEWS-LETTER extends congratulations.
The NEWS-LETTER is glad to announce that, through rigid economy and careful managership, it
has greatly reduced the heavy
debt under which it was left last
year.
SENIORS DISCUSS SENIOR WEEK;
DRAW UP EXEMPTION PETITION.

A meeting of the junior class
was held in the M. E. building on
Thursday, May 8th, for the purposes of collecting money for the
band, and for arranging a program for Senior Week. After
discussing the latter proposition
at length without arriving at a
conclusion, the class decided that
a committee should be appointed to investigate the matter.
Hooper, Stanley, Schmidt, Hancock and Tull were appointed,
and these men are expected to
have a report ready next week.
Carneal, the chairman of the banquet committee announced that
his committee held a balance of
about $12.00, which would go toward defraying the expenses of the
coining festivities. The president,
in a touching little speech,
thanked Mr. Carneal and the
committee for their efforts on
behalf of the class.
The class then decided that a
petition to the Board of Collegiate Studies, should be drawn
up, to exempt seniors, whose records have been creditable, from
final examination. Hooper was
authorized to write such a petition, and to present it to all seniors for their signatures. The
petition has already been passed
around; the reasons given are
first, the collegiate year ends so
late that the additional time required for .examinations will interfere with future plans; and,
second, that final examinations
are deemed unnecessary for seniors who have done well in the
past.

NEWS-LETTER EDITOR-IN-CHIEF
FOR COMING YEAR ELECTED.

John H. Lewin, of the class of
1921, was elected editor-in-chief
of the NEWS-LETTER for the coming year at the Board meeting
Monday. Mr. Lewin is a prominent member of the junior class,
being president of the Debating
Council, a member of the 'Varsity
debating team, a member of the
cast in the Dramatic Club production, and a participant in
other activities.
Lewin succeeds Aylett B. Coleman, of the junior class, who tendered his resignation last week
because his duties next year
would prevent him from giving
his full time to the paper. Coleman expressed the wish to help
the new editor in every way,
especially with the remaining issues of this year.
Frederick F. Torsch, '20, was
elected to the position of managing editor. The resignations of
Field, Hooper, Simon and Miller,
all of the senior class, have been
accepted by the Board.
The newly elected members are
Edward Huey, H. Douglas Cotton,
J. Wilson Duffy and Howard B.
E.
Iensel, all members of the freshman class.
At Other Colleges.

At Brown, a committee of nonathletic organizations is considering a proposition to recognize
work in non-athletic activities
with insignia of some sort, after
the fashion of the "B" in. athletics. A pin or badge will probably be decided upon.

DEBATING COUNCIL ELECTS
OFFICERS FOR NEXT YEAR.

John H. Lewin was elected
president, and R. Graham Heiner
secretary and treasurer, of the
Johns Hopkins Debating Council
for next year, at a meeting held on
May 8. Lewin succeeds Roszel C.
Thomsen, who is a member of the•
graduating class.
Warren M. Driver, Jr., and John
Bartels, from the Class of 1920,
Charles Stein from 1921, and
George Goetz from 1922, were
elected to the Council.
The new Council hopes to get
inter-collegiate debating under

way much earlier next year, and
the secretary will be instructed to
make early arrangements with
the Universities of Virginia and
North Carolina. It is hoped that
the old triangle, so satisfactory
in the past, will be continued.

Capable Cast, Coached by Miss Walter
Gives Excellent Production of Shaw's
"You Never Can Tell"—Female
Characters Attractive.

WAGNER'S

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club made its debut on Wednesday evening, May 7, at Albaugh's
Theatre, where it presented
George Bernard Shaw's four act
comedy, "You Never Can Tell:"
The play is a satire on modern
education, and although the lines,
for the most part, are very clever,
the humor in some instances seems
forced. The acting of all the members of the cast was excellent,
and, in particular, the men impersonating female characters
seemed made for their roles.
The play was produced under
the personal direction of Miss
Clementine Walter, whose remarkable talents and untiring efforts made the performance possible. She not only coached the
men with infinite patience, but she
also designed the costumes.
The character of the philosophic
waiter, filled by George U. Carneal,required great histrionic ability. To impersonate a man seventy years of age, of inferior social
standing, the confidante of so obstrepterous a family, who grasps
every situation with consummate
tact, is a part for a professional
of no common powers. The acting
of Carneal, however, could hardly
have been improved upon.
The female characters were very
natural, but caused convulsions of
laughter throughout the audience.
John Lewin, with his mincing
gestures, dainty form and falsetto
voice, was a wonderful twentieth
century mother, while Edward
Norris, his daughter, not only
stole the heart of the hero, but incidentally broke those important
organs of the male members of
the audience. Terry Burger, a bubblingly enthusiastic _high school
girl, carried off hi part, a difficult one, very well, and received
much applause.
Charles Leber, who took the
part of Mr. Valentine, dentist, and
the hero of the love story, made a
hit. This clever "duellist of sex"
wooed Gloria in a quite modern
and approved fashion, and the
kisses which he so affectionately
administered put the entire audience in a sentimental mood.
Bartus Trew showed ability as
a sixteen-year-old man of the
world, while Heiner successfully
acted the part of Mr. Crampton,
a peeved old man. Morriss was
good as Mr. McComas, although
he naturally exhibited marked
consternation w ii e n Dorothea
made repeated, but ineffectual, attempts, to kiss him. Waters and
Mossom played Maid and Second
Waiter, respectively.
Simon, as Mr. Bohun, the lawyer, dominated the fourth act. A
man of harsh force, a quite definite personality, he fascinated the

The nominations for the General Athletic Board were made

Firor, Tiffany Williams, J. S.

Sutton.
Senior Delegates (3) :• Ferdinand Meyer, G. Cattanach, T.
Burger, W. Driver, S. Silberstein,
E. S. Daugherty, C. Leber.
Junior Delegates (2): W. A.
Crist, Edward Cashell, K. R.
-Mullikin, C. Gould, B. Van Ness,
J. M. Jones, B. Kennady.

H. Wood, Richard Tome, C. Roland Sharretts.
As most of the men nominated
are active in athletics, the Board
will be well able to handle all
athletic matters.

Discusses Relative Importance of Sports
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LEI-1mi.

Sir—It seems to me that some
adjustment is needed in the proportion of importance which we
give to each of our sports. We all
recognize that lacrosse is the
game in which Hopkins specializes
and excels. No one will deny
that lacrosse is one of the prettiest games played, but the fact
remains that at most institutions
it is.unknown, or at best a minor
sport. At several colleges and
universities it is true that it is a
major sport, but at perhaps none
is it given as much preference as
here. In order to draw public
attention we must cater to public taste, and at present public
taste is not fondest of lacrosse. To
bring honor to the Black and
Blue we cannot afford to sacrifice track, tennis, baseball, and
even football, to a game which is
considered less important. To
overcome this prevalent difficulty
one of two things must be done:
either we must persuade more
colleges and universities to adopt
lacrosse as their big spring game,
or we must stop giving our best
material to a game which we all
love, but which does not do the
utmost good for Hopkins.
Surely one or the other of these
courses could be adopted, and the
additional publicity either would
cast on Hopkins would without a
doubt justify whatever sacrifice
would be entailed.
G.F. N.
HOPKINS FRESHMEN TRY
TO OUT RIVAL JULES VERNE.

Two Hopkins freshmen had a
unique experience when they
started off in the cross-country
Victory Loan Balloon, which was
cast loose at the sunken gardens
on St. Paul street on May 6. It
was a real hydrogen-gas balloon,
propelled only by the gentle
breezes, carrying besides the pilot
four enthusiastic passengers, including "Star" Lovell and John
Markel'. The greatest thrill of
all was the getting off, for as
there were many candidates
around the balloon with $10,000
worth of bonds, lots had to be
drawn.
In five minutes from the time
when the lines were cast loose, the
balloon was 5,500 feet in the air,
and kept going up at the same
rate until it was far above the
clouds. The aerial travelers, after being up fifty-five minutes,

Two very pretty girls met on
the street and kissed each other
rapturously. Two young men
watched the meeting. "There's
another of those things that are
so unfair," said one.
"What is that?" said his friend.
He pointed to the scene: "Women
doing men's work."—Ex.
experiencing many thrills and
for a lono. time believing that
they were6headed for the Chesapeake Bay, came down and finally
landed near Pimlico.
"I had an irresistable desire to
yank on that red cord when we
were way up there," said the
"Admiral" to John, when they
were safe back on Mother Earth.
"It's a good thing you didn't,"
said the other, "that was the rip
cord. As for me, I never wanted
to light a cigarette more in my
life than wh.,n we were under
that hydrogen gas."
The loneliness of the situation
over a mile up is what impressed
the travelers most. For that reason, their friends have had to
listen to their experiences ever
since the event.

The Alumni Association, the
Alumni Council, the Johns Hopkins Club, and other alumni organizations are co-operating in a
movement for a general reunion
of Hopkins alumni in June. This
will be the first gathering of former Hopkins men since the move
to Homewood was made. There
had been an insistent call for a
number of years from the alumni
that the University be moved to
Homewood. They will now have
an opportunity to see what a
splendid start has been made by
the University in that direction
and to form an impression as to
what there is yet to be done to
complete the job.
The principal reason for having
a reunion at this time is that it
is a most appropriate time for all
to unite in memorial exercises to
those of the alumni who have lost
their lives in the World War. It
will also afford a splendid opportunity to pay fit tribute to
alumni who have, returned from
the war and to welcome them.
The plans for the reunion are
still somewhat incomplete. They
will include an inspection of
Homewood by the alumni, memorial exercises to the dead and
the erection of a memorial tablet.
A number of features of a lighter
nature will be incorporated; for
instance, a lacrosse game with
the University of Toronto a baseball game, a smoker at the Johns
Hopkins Club, a review of the R.
0. T. C. battalion, class and department dinners and reunions.
Theoretically speaking, the reunion will come to an end Saturday night, June 21. A number
of very interesting features are
planned, however, for the interval
between that date and the commencement on June 24. A number of very prominent officials of
the United States and Canada
will be present at this time
time, and
a cable was sent to Dr.

Dr. Osler.
If the Peace Conference does
not interfere, the committee plans
to have present at the meeting. President Wilson, Secretary
Baker, both Hopkins alumni, and
also the Prime Minister of Canada.

HIGH GRADE CHOCOLATES.

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Yale is the pioneer in restricting the number of activities in
which one student may take part.
All of the offices and memberships are divided into three
classes, and no man may accept
more than a certain number in
each class. In the recently held
elections for next year the system was followed. It has attracted considerable interest in
other colleges, and a similar proposal is to be made at Dartmouth.
The new system will be very
helpful as a measure against the
ascendancy of "job hogs," as certain members of the community
are respectfully named.
• *
Swarthmore raised over seven
hundred dollars in a recent campaign of the Child Labor committee.
* * *
Washington and Lee has established an honor system canteen,.
carrying on business without
even a clerk, and having all customers wait on themselves.
Dean Briggs of Harvard says
that tutors should be professors
with a voice'in the affairs of the
University, and with a permanent
position of honor. He decidedly
disfavors the seasonal coaching
system.

The annual Government inspectiOn of the R. 0. T. C. unit will
be held on .May 19 and 20. Col.
J. B. Douglas, of the General
Staff, will act as inspector. Judging from the way the R. 0. T. C.
has been drilling recently, and
from the plans that are laid, it
looks as though Hopkins will
maintain its old record for efficiency in R. 0. T. C. work. For
the inspection, there will be three
companies with cadet officers. All
members of the unit will form in
one or another of these companies.
LECTURER DISCUSSES "ORE DOCK
ON THE GREAT LAKES."

Last week's J. E. Aldred Lecture was on the subject of "Ore
Docks on the Great Lakes," and
was given by Mr..John E. Greiner,
consulting engineer of this city.
The chief topics dwelt upon were
the expansion of the ore-handling
business, the construction of the
docks (both loading and unloading) and the types of unloading
machinery.
The speaker began with saying
that the Sault Ste Marie Canal increased the shipments of ore from
1,450 tons to 36,000 in one year,
and that last year the output had
increased to 61,000,000 tons. Most
of the deposits are along the
southern shore of Lake Superior;
hence, the docks there are of the
loading kind, with high bins and
chutes to deliver the ore by gravity into the holds of the steamers.
The unloading docks along
Lakes Michigan, Erie and Huron
have huge scoops and buckets for
lifting the ore from the holds of•
the steamers and depositing it
upon storage piles or in cars. The
scoops act like giant hands, turning and twisting into every corner, under the control of the driver, who sometimes sits in a compartment on the scoop and sometimes on the crane.
This field of engineering, which
includes the design of docks and
their machinery, and the operation
and upkeep of the same, is still
in its infancy. The rapid growth
before the war and the wide possibilities of development in the future will afford many openings
for the young engineers.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAY 13, 1919

The June Reunion.

IS

The Alumni Reu nion, scheduled
for the latter part of June, should
be of great value to the University. Three of the main features
on the program are a thorough
inspection of the Homewood
buildings by the alumni, many
of whom have never seen Hopkins in its up-town home; memorial exercises, including the
erection of a memorial tablet to
the dead; and a welcome to Hopkins' sons who have returned
from overseas.
The alumni long advocated the
change of site from down-town
to Homewood; and now they, will
have a chance to see what is still
needed in the way of buildings
and equipment. The lack of adequate dormitories, a gym, laboratory buildings and the like, will
immediately be apparent. The
alumni are seeking a permanent
memorial for Hopkins men who
made the supreme sacrifice.
What could be more suitable than
a memorial dormitory or gymnasium?
It would be fitting for the present to have tablets to perpetuate
the memory of those who gave
their lives, but in the near future
a memorial building should by all
means be erected. Princeton is
considering for this purpose a
chapel; Washington and Lee, an
arch, and Lehigh is carrying on
a most successful campaign for a

memorial administration building, the first $100,000 having been
contributed by fifty men. The
Hopkins alumni are looked to to
help put the thing across for us;
and the reunion in June will
probably start a Hopkins memorial campaign.
The reunion plans and the
names of prominent alumni and
officials who will attend the reunion appear in another part of
the NEWS-LETTER. Mr. George
Radcliffe, president of the Alumni
Association, is exerting every effort for the success of the alumni
get-together. The students and
faculty, by their co-operation and
enthusiasm, can do much to aid
him and the committees in
charge. We should lend our aid
in every way toward making the
exercises in June one of the greatest events in the history of the
University. The NEWS-LETTER IS
planning to do its part by issuing
a special alumni number to be
sent to all parts of the country,
with the intention of interesting
the alumni.
The reunion, which will last
through commencement, will tend
to make the finals this year more
eventful. More elaborate finals
traditions would certainly be
most beneficial to Hopkins. The
Princeton finals, for example,
with their combination of dignity,
impressiveness and gaiety, are
the crowning event of the year.
Every class with surviving members returns to pay homage to its
Alma Mater. Each class has
its separate headquarters, where
song and reminiscence—and in
the future, Bevo — hold sway.
Social events for both undergraduates and older men crowd the
calendar. The alumni thus renew their zeal for Princeton and
form a veritable army to back it
financially and in every other
way.
Here at Hopkins, however, the
termination of the final exams
marks the closing of the year for
many. When the last dread
ordeal is a thing of the past, they
immediately repair to home or
resort. We hope that the coming
Alumni Reunion will be a forerunner of real Hopkins finals, in
which every class since the founding of the University and every
undergraduate will take an active
part.
Were You There?

The performance of the track
artists and stickmen Saturday
deserved better attendance. The
fair-weather rooters evidently
preferred the sheltering coziness
of some tea emporium to the cold
drizzle of Homewood field—or,
perhaps, hearing at Friday's
mass-meeting of the fate of all
head-gears not of the straw variety, and fearing the rain's effect on their new Knox, they just
didn't know what to wear. At
all events, they would have been
'rewarded for any trouble just to
have witnessed the lacrosse game,

which resulted in such a fiasco
for the Philadelphians. If the
Black and Blue stickmen can repeat next Saturday against
Lehigh, they will again bring the
championship to Hopkins.
The names of the nominees for
election to the G. A. A., appear
elsewhere in the NEWS-LETTER.
Consider them carefully and don't
fail to be present at the massmeeting Thursday. Your fee of
ten dollars makes you a stockholder in the Athletic Association. You surely want to help
determine its policy by voting for
your candidate. All out Thursday!
Particular attention has been
given NEWS-LETTER candidates
this year, for each has received
an informal grade on his work
every week. The four men who
were elected Monday have shown
the most dependability and talent
so far; others, however, will probably be elected before the end of
the year. The NEWS-LETTER extends congratulations.
The NEWS-LETTER is glad to announce that, through rigid economy and careful managership, it
has greatly reduced the heavy
debt under which it was left last
year.
SENIORS DISCUSS SENIOR WEEK;
DRAW UP EXEMPTION PETITION.

A meeting of the junior class
was held in the M. E. building on
Thursday, May 8th, for the purposes of collecting money for the
band, and for arranging a program for Senior Week. After
discussing the latter proposition
at length without arriving at a
conclusion, the class decided that
a committee should be appointed to investigate the matter.
Hooper, Stanley, Schmidt, Hancock and Tull were appointed,
and these men are expected to
have a report ready next week.
Carneal, the chairman of the banquet committee announced that
his committee held a balance of
about $12.00, which would go toward defraying the expenses of the
coining festivities. The president,
in a touching little speech,
thanked Mr. Carneal and the
committee for their efforts on
behalf of the class.
The class then decided that a
petition to the Board of Collegiate Studies, should be drawn
up, to exempt seniors, whose records have been creditable, from
final examination. Hooper was
authorized to write such a petition, and to present it to all seniors for their signatures. The
petition has already been passed
around; the reasons given are
first, the collegiate year ends so
late that the additional time required for .examinations will interfere with future plans; and,
second, that final examinations
are deemed unnecessary for seniors who have done well in the
past.

NEWS-LETTER EDITOR-IN-CHIEF
FOR COMING YEAR ELECTED.

John H. Lewin, of the class of
1921, was elected editor-in-chief
of the NEWS-LETTER for the coming year at the Board meeting
Monday. Mr. Lewin is a prominent member of the junior class,
being president of the Debating
Council, a member of the 'Varsity
debating team, a member of the
cast in the Dramatic Club production, and a participant in
other activities.
Lewin succeeds Aylett B. Coleman, of the junior class, who tendered his resignation last week
because his duties next year
would prevent him from giving
his full time to the paper. Coleman expressed the wish to help
the new editor in every way,
especially with the remaining issues of this year.
Frederick F. Torsch, '20, was
elected to the position of managing editor. The resignations of
Field, Hooper, Simon and Miller,
all of the senior class, have been
accepted by the Board.
The newly elected members are
Edward Huey, H. Douglas Cotton,
J. Wilson Duffy and Howard B.
E.
Iensel, all members of the freshman class.

At Brown, a committee of nonathletic organizations is considering a proposition to recognize
work in non-athletic activities
with insignia of some sort, after
the fashion of the "B" in. athletics. A pin or badge will probably be decided upon.

John H. Lewin was elected
president, and R. Graham Heiner
secretary and treasurer, of the
Johns Hopkins Debating Council
for next year, at a meeting held on
May 8. Lewin succeeds Roszel C.
Thomsen, who is a member of the•
graduating class.
Warren M. Driver, Jr., and John
Bartels, from the Class of 1920,
Charles Stein from 1921, and
George Goetz from 1922, were
elected to the Council.
The new Council hopes to get
inter-collegiate debating under

way much earlier next year, and
the secretary will be instructed to
make early arrangements with
the Universities of Virginia and
North Carolina. It is hoped that
the old triangle, so satisfactory
in the past, will be continued.

Capable Cast, Coached by Miss Walter
Gives Excellent Production of Shaw's
"You Never Can Tell"—Female
Characters Attractive.

WAGNER'S

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic
Club made its debut on Wednesday evening, May 7, at Albaugh's
Theatre, where it presented
George Bernard Shaw's four act
comedy, "You Never Can Tell:"
The play is a satire on modern
education, and although the lines,
for the most part, are very clever,
the humor in some instances seems
forced. The acting of all the members of the cast was excellent,
and, in particular, the men impersonating female characters
seemed made for their roles.
The play was produced under
the personal direction of Miss
Clementine Walter, whose remarkable talents and untiring efforts made the performance possible. She not only coached the
men with infinite patience, but she
also designed the costumes.
The character of the philosophic
waiter, filled by George U. Carneal,required great histrionic ability. To impersonate a man seventy years of age, of inferior social
standing, the confidante of so obstrepterous a family, who grasps
every situation with consummate
tact, is a part for a professional
of no common powers. The acting
of Carneal, however, could hardly
have been improved upon.
The female characters were very
natural, but caused convulsions of
laughter throughout the audience.
John Lewin, with his mincing
gestures, dainty form and falsetto
voice, was a wonderful twentieth
century mother, while Edward
Norris, his daughter, not only
stole the heart of the hero, but incidentally broke those important
organs of the male members of
the audience. Terry Burger, a bubblingly enthusiastic _high school
girl, carried off hi part, a difficult one, very well, and received
much applause.
Charles Leber, who took the
part of Mr. Valentine, dentist, and
the hero of the love story, made a
hit. This clever "duellist of sex"
wooed Gloria in a quite modern
and approved fashion, and the
kisses which he so affectionately
administered put the entire audience in a sentimental mood.
Bartus Trew showed ability as
a sixteen-year-old man of the
world, while Heiner successfully
acted the part of Mr. Crampton,
a peeved old man. Morriss was
good as Mr. McComas, although
he naturally exhibited marked
consternation w ii e n Dorothea
made repeated, but ineffectual, attempts, to kiss him. Waters and
Mossom played Maid and Second
Waiter, respectively.
Simon, as Mr. Bohun, the lawyer, dominated the fourth act. A
man of harsh force, a quite definite personality, he fascinated the

Discusses Relative Importance of Sports
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LEI-1mi.

Sir—It seems to me that some
adjustment is needed in the proportion of importance which we
give to each of our sports. We all
recognize that lacrosse is the
game in which Hopkins specializes
and excels. No one will deny
that lacrosse is one of the prettiest games played, but the fact
remains that at most institutions
it is.unknown, or at best a minor
sport. At several colleges and
universities it is true that it is a
major sport, but at perhaps none
is it given as much preference as
here. In order to draw public
attention we must cater to public taste, and at present public
taste is not fondest of lacrosse. To
bring honor to the Black and
Blue we cannot afford to sacrifice track, tennis, baseball, and
even football, to a game which is
considered less important. To
overcome this prevalent difficulty
one of two things must be done:
either we must persuade more
colleges and universities to adopt
lacrosse as their big spring game,
or we must stop giving our best
material to a game which we all
love, but which does not do the
utmost good for Hopkins.
Surely one or the other of these
courses could be adopted, and the
additional publicity either would
cast on Hopkins would without a
doubt justify whatever sacrifice
would be entailed.
G.F. N.
HOPKINS FRESHMEN TRY
TO OUT RIVAL JULES VERNE.

Two Hopkins freshmen had a
unique experience when they
started off in the cross-country
Victory Loan Balloon, which was
cast loose at the sunken gardens
on St. Paul street on May 6. It
was a real hydrogen-gas balloon,
propelled only by the gentle
breezes, carrying besides the pilot
four enthusiastic passengers, including "Star" Lovell and John
Markel'. The greatest thrill of
all was the getting off, for as
there were many candidates
around the balloon with $10,000
worth of bonds, lots had to be
drawn.
In five minutes from the time
when the lines were cast loose, the
balloon was 5,500 feet in the air,
and kept going up at the same
rate until it was far above the
clouds. The aerial travelers, after being up fifty-five minutes,

Two very pretty girls met on
the street and kissed each other
rapturously. Two young men
watched the meeting. "There's
another of those things that are
so unfair," said one.
"What is that?" said his friend.
He pointed to the scene: "Women
doing men's work."—Ex.
experiencing many thrills and
for a lono. time believing that
they were6headed for the Chesapeake Bay, came down and finally
landed near Pimlico.
"I had an irresistable desire to
yank on that red cord when we
were way up there," said the
"Admiral" to John, when they
were safe back on Mother Earth.
"It's a good thing you didn't,"
said the other, "that was the rip
cord. As for me, I never wanted
to light a cigarette more in my
life than wh.,n we were under
that hydrogen gas."
The loneliness of the situation
over a mile up is what impressed
the travelers most. For that reason, their friends have had to
listen to their experiences ever
since the event.
